question.text: The standard enthalpy of formation $\left(\Delta_f \mathrm{H}^{\circ}{ }_{298}\right)$ for methane, $\mathrm{CH}_4$ is $-74.9 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. In order to calculate the average energy given out in the formation of a $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{H}$ bond from this it is necessary to know which one of the following?

options.text: The dissociation energy of the hydrogen molecule, $\mathrm{H}_2$.
The first four ionisation energies of carbon.
The dissociation energy of $\mathrm{H}_2$ and enthalpy and sublimation of carbon (graphite).
The first four ionisation energies of carbon and electron affinity of hydrogen.

solution.text:
To calculate average enthalpy of $\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{H}$ bond in methane following informations are needed
(i) dissociation energy of $\mathrm{H}_2$ i.e.
$$
\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{H}_2(g) \longrightarrow \mathrm{H}(\mathrm{g}) ; \Delta \mathrm{H}=x(\text { suppose } \quad)
$$
(ii) Sublimation energy of $\mathrm{C}$ (graphite) to $\mathrm{C}(g)$ $\mathrm{C}($ graphite $) \longrightarrow \mathrm{C}(g) ; \Delta \mathrm{H}=y$ (Suppose) Given
$\mathrm{C}($ graphite $)+2 \mathrm{H}_2(\mathrm{~g}) \longrightarrow \mathrm{CH}_4(\mathrm{~g}) ; \Delta \mathrm{H}=75 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$
